STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 7, 2022
Ellen Westgate
Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
4925 Packard Road
Ann Arbor, MI 48108-1521
RE: License #: CB810201018
Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
4925 Packard Road
Ann Arbor, MI 48108-1521
Dear Mrs. Westgate:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
1/4/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please indicate why the previous CAP was unsuccessful, and what
changes will be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following: (c) A physical examination
for each child as follows, unless a greater frequency is medically
indicated: (iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of six foster care files did not meet this requirement as the last medical exam on
file was completed on 2/12/20.
REPEAT VIOLATION: 2/10/20 Renewal, CAP approved 2/25/20
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
Two of six foster care files were missing monthly home visits. One file did not have a
monthly FHV documented for February 2021, the other did not have a visit
documented for March 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION: 1/27/21 Interim, CAP approved 2/16/21
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(3) The report shall be an assessment of all of the following:
(f) Safety and maintenance of the applicant's house and,
property, including but not limited to: sufficient beds and
sleeping space, pets, guns and other weapons, and water
hazards.
One of six adoptive home studies reported the family had a pool. However, the study
did not identify safety measures such as a door alarm or rescue equipment.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
4

FOM 722-05 Case Documentation
Page 2-3
MDHHS and private child placing agencies must maintain all
case documentation in the child's electronic case record in
MiSACWIS.
MDHHS and private child placing agencies must upload
documentation according to the guidelines in the MiSACWIS
Job Aid: Uploading Documents.
One of six adoption files did not have any documents uploaded for the adoptive
parent assessment.
REPEAT VIOLATION: 2/10/20 Renewal, CAP approved 2/25/20
FOM 801-01 Health Requirements
Dental examinations are required for children one year of age
and older, as follows: A dental re-examination shall be obtained
at least every six months unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
Four of six foster care files had late or missing dental exams.
File one: A dental exam occurred on 3/2/20; an updated exam was on 11/16/21.
File two: A dental exam occurred on 12/2/20; an updated exam is not on file.
File three: A dental exam occurred on 12/30/20; an updated exam is not on file.
File four: A dental exam occurred on 2/12/20; an updated exam is not on file.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Pages 3-5
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables… Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Three of six foster care files did not meet this requirement.
File one: 5/14/21 and 8/11/21 USPs did not have FTMs.
File two: 4/11/21 USP did not have an FTM.
File three: 5/20/21, 8/23/21 and 10/26/21 USPs did not have FTMs.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/27/21 Interim, CAP approved 2/16/21
2/10/20 Renewal, CAP approved 2/25/20
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Pages 2-3
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information… Receipt of the
medical passport by the above listed parties is documented in
5

MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated signature page
into the Health Profile section.
Three of six foster care files did not meet this requirement.
File one: A quarterly update was not completed for July 2021.
File two: Only one medical passport was on file for the past year.
File three: A quarterly update was not completed for July 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION: 1/27/21 Interim, CAP approved 2/16/21
FOM 723 Educational Services
Page 17
The education section of MiSACWIS should be updated at the
end of each school year to reflect when a child completes a
grade and advances to the next or if they are repeating the
same grade. Each school year should be end dated with an end
grade listed.
Three of six foster care files did not have an end of the year update or report card for
the 2020/2021 school year.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Page 10
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable… The
caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Three of sixteen PATPs had late signatures.
File one: The 8/23/21 PATP was not signed by the foster parent until 11/23/21.
File two: The 9/3/21 PATP was not signed by the foster parent until 10/12/21.
File three: The 8/14/21 PATP was not signed by the caregiver until 11/21/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/27/21 Interim, CAP approved 2/16/21 (Previously cited under 722-08C)
SRM 200 Fingerprints
Page 16
All personnel, contractors, vendors, and external auditors who
have access to CW-CHRI are required to complete Security
Awareness Training (SAT).
SAT is required to be taken within six months of working in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
A review of Security Awareness Training found that four staff did not complete the
training within the required timeframe.
6

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 The agency was reminded to generate/save reports, to make them accessible
under the documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS. The agency also was advised to
contact the help desk if they have any problems with reports; then document the
contact and ticket number for the issue.
 PATPs must have dates with the signatures to verify they were signed within the
required timeframe.
 For licensing renewals and annuals, the 4004 report and 3080 compliance record
must both identify the agency’s recommendation, including specifics such as the
number of children, age, gender, and characteristics. Information on the 4004
and 3080 should match.
 When completing a licensing annual report (4004) the 3706 does not need to be
signed by the worker and supervisor unless changes to the license are
requested.
 Signatures- The MDHHS Policy office recently clarified that PATPs and Medical
Passports need to be signed by any non-respondent parent that has placement
of their child. This non-respondent parent must sign as the ‘placement provider’.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following area:
 The agency asked for guidance regarding the COVID-19 vaccine for foster youth.
After consultation with the MDHHS policy office, the agency was informed CI 21-
004 (updated 11/8/21) indicates all vaccines are considered routine medical care
and do not require formal consent by the court or MCI. Children should receive
their COVID-19 vaccine unless their medical provider indicated the child should
not receive it due to a medical condition, or if the parent of a temporary court
ward refuses the vaccine.
7

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
A CAP, approved 2/16/21, was required after the 1/27/21 interim inspection. The
2021 inspection found 10 violations of licensing rules and DHHS contract. The
2/10/20 renewal inspection found 13 violations. During the current review, six repeat
violations were found. However, it should be noted the agency has made many
changes over the past year, including a new chief administrator, and additional staff.
These changes have supported many improvements and it is anticipated these
areas will continue to improve over the next year.
A CAP, approved 7/8/21, was required after special investigation 2021C0207012
was completed on 6/14/21. The investigation determined violation of rules 309
Records check, 319 Substitute care policy, 206 Staff qualifications, and 327 Special
evaluations. These violations were found due a foster home having an unapproved
person living in the home. The agency became aware of the situation but did not
address it appropriately or complete a thorough investigation per licensing rules. At
this time, the issue with the foster home has been resolved. The agency has
implemented their CAP and no further concerns were determined.
A CAP, approved 8/31/2021, was required after special investigation 2021C0207019
was completed on 8/10/21. The investigation determined a repeat violation of rule
325 License recommendation and a violation of rule 404 Placement. These
violations were found due to special evaluation reports lacking content required by
licensing rules and due to the foster home’s license not specifying a placement type
they had accepted. The agency has implemented their CAP and no further concerns
were determined.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed during the
entrance meeting on 12/13/21. The Chief Administrator (CA) is new to the position
this year and reports the transition to have gone well. The CA reported the agency
has been understaffed over the past three years, which has resulted in difficulty
meeting licensing/contract requirements. This year a full-time licensing, foster care
and adoption staff were all added. A part time licensing worker was also added, but
later left. The CA reported the CAP from the 2021 Interim assessment was
implemented immediately and included new practices, updated forms, additional
training, and supervision. Clerical staff have also assisted with tracking due dates,
which has assisted case workers. Administration has been reviewing case files,
CAPS, and following-up with staff. Staff are included in reviews and reminders on a
regular basis, which has helped with compliance and made staff more aware of
8

requirements and expectations. The result has been that staff have become more
confident in their work and able to assist co-workers when needed. Overall, the CA
reports feeling positive about the changes during this past year.
Interviews
Two staff members were interviewed and reported significant positive changes over
the past year. Both staff indicated the CAP from 2021 is reviewed frequently and has
helped the agency improve in several areas. Neither staff had any concerns
regarding the agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, and contract/policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be
issued a renewal of their regular license.
_ _________________January 6, 2022_____________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 7, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
